holidays.name: No Interruptions Day
holidays.description: A day dedicated to living peacefully and avoiding any form of interruptions—whether at work, home, or play. It's all about serenity in your last moments of the year!
holidays.origin: Created by author and humorist Tom Hodgkinson, who suggested this day to appreciate the value of uninterrupted time.
holidays.funFact: No Interruptions Day encourages you to wear a ‘Do Not Disturb’ sign and enjoy some blissful silence—good luck with that on New Year's Eve!

holidays.name: Make Up Your Mind Day
holidays.description: A quirky reminder to stop procrastinating and make those tough choices you've been avoiding—perfect timing as the year ends!
holidays.origin: Traced back to motivational campaigns encouraging decisiveness.
holidays.funFact: Deciding what to order for dinner on New Year’s Eve counts as practicing for Make Up Your Mind Day.

holidays.name: World Cat Herders Day
holidays.description: An unofficial holiday for those with jobs that involve managing the seemingly impossible or herding cats—literally or figuratively.
holidays.origin: Inspired by the saying 'like herding cats' to describe chaotic tasks.
holidays.funFact: It's celebrated on December 31 because even herders deserve a day off during the busy holidays!

holidays.name: Polar Bear Drop (Anchorage)
holidays.description: An annual New Year’s Eve tradition in Anchorage, Alaska, where a giant polar bear made of styrofoam is dropped from a crane at midnight to kick off the New Year.
holidays.origin: Started in 1982 to give Anchorage a festive twist on the traditional 'ball drop'.
holidays.funFact: The Polar Bear Drop replaces the usual ball drop with an Alaskan wildlife twist; participants often watch in parka-clad excitement!
